transcript:
Hello Everyone! My name is Princess, and today I am presenting my valuation of Panera Bread for a potential takeover by KKR for Session 12 Assignment

The purpose of this assignment is to simulate professional level financial analysis, synthesizing everything we have learned this semester, from Time Value of Money to Cost of Capital, into a single investment decision.

I followed the DRIVER Framework throughout. This ensures systematic analysis and quality control at each stage. We will walk through all six stages: Discover, Represent, Implement, Validate, Evolve, and Reflect.

Starting with Discover and Design. We identify the problem and frame the deal.

As you can see on the right, here is our deal snapshot.

Revenue is 6 billion dollars, growing at 8 percent annually. EBITDA is 900 million dollars, that is a 15 percent margin. Net Income is 400 million dollars. The company has 2,100 stores with 50 percent digital sales, which is a key competitive advantage.

The key constraints, summarized on the left.

KKR is a financial buyer with no synergies. But Starbucks and McDonald's are circling. They are strategic buyers who can extract synergies. Management wants 10 percent equity rollover, signaling they believe in the upside.

This sets up our central challenge. How do we compete against buyers who can justify paying more?

My objective is to build a triangulated valuation and recommend a disciplined bid strategy for KKR.

Moving to Represent. This is the planning phase where we map our analytical framework and assumptions.

The foundation of any DCF is the discount rate. I calculated WACC using CAPM.

Risk free rate is 4.5 percent based on the 10 year Treasury. Beta is 0.90 for the restaurant industry. Market risk premium is 5.5 percent. This gives us cost of equity of 9.4 percent. After tax cost of debt is 4.5 percent. With a 70 30 equity debt structure, WACC rounds to 9 percent.

Remember, WACC represents the minimum return required by all capital providers. It is our hurdle rate.

Next, I built three scenarios to capture uncertainty.

Base Case has revenue growth from 8 percent declining to 4 percent over 5 years. EBITDA margin expands from 15 percent to 17 percent from operating leverage. Terminal growth is 2.5 percent.

Upside Case has 10 percent to 5 percent growth, margins expanding to 19 percent, and WACC of 8.5 percent.

Downside Case has 6 percent to 3 percent growth, flat 15 percent margins, and WACC of 10 percent.

For market validation, I selected 6 comparable companies: Chipotle, McDonald's, Starbucks, Yum, Darden, and Domino's. The median is 17.5x EV to EBITDA.

I also selected 6 precedent transactions, including JAB acquiring Panera at 14.5x. The median is 12.5x EV to EBITDA.

Now Implement. We execute the models and generate outputs.

Starting with the DCF. My model calculates Free Cash Flow as NOPAT plus D and A, minus CapEx, minus change in working capital. FCF is the true measure of cash available to investors.

Base Case Results. Year 1 FCF is 509 million dollars. Year 5 FCF is 756 million dollars. Present value of cash flows is 2.4 billion dollars. Terminal Value is 11.9 billion dollars with a present value of 7.8 billion dollars. Enterprise Value comes to 10.2 billion dollars. That is 11.3x EBITDA.

Upside case gives 14.4 billion dollars at 16x. Downside case gives 6.7 billion dollars at 7.5x.

Applying the median 17.5x comp multiple, implied EV is 15.8 billion dollars. The range is 14.6 billion to 17.6 billion. Comps run higher because they include growth names like Chipotle.

Using the 12.5x precedent median, implied EV is 11.2 billion dollars. The range is 9.4 billion to 13.5 billion. This is more relevant for an M and A scenario.

Now the critical analysis. Financial versus Strategic Buyer.

I quantified synergies in three categories.

Store overlap is 200 locations times 150 thousand dollars savings, which equals 30 million dollars per year.

Digital scale includes tech consolidation plus cross sell, which equals 125 million dollars per year.

Operating leverage includes procurement plus G and A, which equals 100 million dollars per year.

Total annual synergies are 255 million dollars. Capitalized at 8x, that is 2.0 billion dollars in synergy value.

Strategic buyer max is 12.2 billion dollars versus our standalone 10.2 billion dollars.

That is a 2 billion dollar gap we need to overcome with speed and certainty.

But synergies are not guaranteed. Risks include culture clash, brand dilution, 5 to 10 percent customer attrition, and typically only 60 to 80 percent of synergies are realized.

Risk adjusted synergy value at 70 percent is 1.4 billion dollars.

The Validate phase is our quality control. We verify the model makes sense.

Check 1 is Terminal Value. It is 76 percent of enterprise value. The benchmark is 60 to 80 percent for growth companies. Pass.

Check 2 is Implied Multiple. DCF implies 11.3x EBITDA. Precedent range is 10.5x to 15x. Pass.

Check 3 is Revenue CAGR. It is 6 percent over 5 years. This is reasonable deceleration from 8 percent historical. Pass.

Check 4 is Cross Method Comparison. DCF gives 10.2 billion. Comps give 15.8 billion. Precedents give 11.2 billion.

The spread exists because comps include high growth public stocks. For M and A, precedents and DCF are more relevant.

All validation checks pass. The model is robust.

Now Evolve. We synthesize everything into a single view.

This is the Football Field. It consolidates all methods visually.

DCF Downside is 6.7 billion. DCF Base is 10.2 billion. DCF Upside is 14.4 billion. Trading Comps range from 14.6 billion to 17.6 billion. Precedent Transactions range from 9.4 billion to 13.5 billion. Strategic Max is 12.2 billion.

The red dashed lines show our bid range.

Triangulated Value uses 50 percent weight to DCF at 10.2 billion, 25 percent weight to Comps at 15.8 billion, and 25 percent weight to Precedents at 11.2 billion. The weighted average is 11.8 billion dollars, or 13.2x EBITDA.

This sits right in the middle of the precedent range. It is defensible and competitive.

Financing Structure at 11.8 billion. Debt at 50 percent is 5.9 billion. Equity at 50 percent is 5.9 billion. Management rollover is 1.2 billion. KKR equity check is 4.7 billion.

Debt metrics show Debt to EBITDA at 6.6x and Interest coverage at 2.2x.

The 10 percent management rollover saves KKR 1.2 billion in equity and aligns incentives.

Finally, Reflect. Our recommendation and bid strategy.

Walk Away price is 6.7 billion at 7.5x. Initial Bid is 10.7 billion at 11.8x. Target Bid is 11.8 billion at 13.2x. Max Bid is 13.0 billion at 14.5x.

Negotiation Talking Points.

First is Value Creation. KKR brings digital transformation expertise and operational playbook.

Second is Deal Certainty. Committed financing with no antitrust risk unlike strategic buyers.

Third is Management Alignment. Supporting the 10 percent rollover shows confidence and retains talent.

Fourth is Speed. KKR can close in 60 to 90 days versus 6 plus months for strategic.

Fifth is Price Discipline. Initial offer at 11.8x is within precedent range with room to 13.2x for exclusivity.

Key Risks. Strategic buyers can outbid by 2 billion dollars. Do not exceed 14.5x because beyond this IRR falls below 20 percent. There is also execution risk on digital transformation.

My Recommendation is to Pursue the Acquisition.

Target price is 11.8 billion dollars at 13.2x EBITDA.

KKR should move aggressively to pre empt a strategic process. Our advantages are speed, certainty, and management alignment.

If price exceeds 13 billion dollars in a bidding war, walk away.

To summarize.

Panera Bread is valued at 11.8 billion dollars based on triangulating DCF, comparables, and precedent transactions.

KKR should bid between 10.7 billion initially and 13 billion maximum, leveraging speed and management alignment to win.

This analysis demonstrates the integration of concepts from across the semester including TVM, WACC, capital budgeting, and stakeholder analysis into a real world investment decision.
Thank you for watching.
